Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle and endurance performance in female athletes - systematic reviews
Citation: McNulty, K.L., Elliott-Sale, K.J., Dolan, E., Swinton, P.A., Ansdell, P., Goodall, S., Thomas, K., & Hicks, K.M. (2020). The Effects of Menstrual Cycle Phase on Exercise Performance in Eumenorrheic Women: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis. Sports Medicine, 50(10), 1813–1827.
Key_Findings: This systematic review and meta-analysis found that exercise performance is trivially reduced during the early follicular phase of the menstrual cycle compared to all other phases. The effect size was very small, and the confidence in the evidence was low due to high variability between studies. The overall conclusion suggests that, on average, performance differences across the menstrual cycle are negligible for most women, but a personalized approach is recommended for elite athletes based on individual responses.

Research_Topic: Female athlete triad and running injuries - longitudinal studies
Citation: Colebatch, E. A., Fuller, J. T., Mantzioris, E., & Hill, A. M. (2025). Diet, risk of disordered eating and running-related injury in adult distance runners: A systematic review and meta-analysis of prospective cohort studies. Journal of Science and Medicine in Sport, 28(7), 542-552.
Study_Design: Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Prospective Cohort Studies
Key_Findings: Moderate certainty evidence indicates that female distance runners with lower energy and total fat intakes are at an increased risk of running-related injury. Specifically, injured female runners had a mean difference of -303 kcal/day and -20 g/day lower energy and fat intake, respectively, compared to uninjured runners. Other dietary factors, including the risk of disordered eating, did not show a significant influence on injury risk.

Research_Topic: Hormonal contraceptives and athletic performance in runners
Citation: Elliott-Sale, K. J., McNulty, K. L., Ansdell, P., Goodall, S., Hicks, K. M., Thomas, K., Swinton, P. A., & Dolan, E. (2020). The Effects of Oral Contraceptives on Exercise Performance in Women: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis. Sports Medicine, 50(10), 1785–1812.
Key_Findings: The systematic review and meta-analysis concluded that oral contraceptive pill (OCP) use results in a trivial, non-significant reduction in exercise performance on average when compared to naturally menstruating women. Performance was consistent across the OCP cycle phases, suggesting that the exogenous hormones do not significantly enhance or impair performance. The authors suggest that individual responses to OCPs are highly variable and more influential than any group-level effect.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle phase and VO2 max in female endurance athletes
Citation: McNulty, K. L., Elliott-Sale, K. J., Dolan, E., Swinton, P. A., Ansdell, P., Goodall, S., Thomas, K., & Hicks, K. M. (2020). The Effects of Menstrual Cycle Phase on Exercise Performance in Eumenorrheic Women: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis. Sports Medicine, 50(10), 1813–1827.
Key_Findings: The systematic review and meta-analysis found that exercise performance, which included VO2 max as an indicator, might be trivially reduced during the early follicular phase of the menstrual cycle compared to all other phases. The largest, though still small, negative effect was observed between the early follicular and late follicular phases. Due to the trivial effect size and large variation across studies, the authors recommend a personalized approach rather than general guidelines for training across the menstrual cycle.

Research_Topic: Progesterone and thermoregulation during exercise in women
Citation: Giersch, G. E. W., Morrissey, M. C., Katch, R. K., Colburn, A. T., Sims, S. T., Stachenfeld, N. S., & Casa, D. J. (2020). Menstrual cycle and thermoregulation during exercise in the heat: A systematic review and meta-analysis. Journal of Science and Medicine in Sport, 23(12), 1134–1140.
Key_Findings: The meta-analysis found that internal body temperature (Tint) was significantly greater in the luteal phase (when progesterone is high) compared to the follicular phase, both before and after exercise. This suggests that the progesterone-driven increase in core temperature is maintained during exercise in the heat. However, the study found no significant differences in mean skin temperature, sweat rate, or exercise heart rate between the menstrual phases, indicating that the body's heat dissipation mechanisms may not be significantly altered by the cycle.

Research_Topic: Estrogen and muscle recovery in female athletes
Citation: Romero-Parra, N., Cupeiro, R., Alfaro-Magallanes, V. M., Rael, B., Rubio-Arias, J. A., Peinado, A. B., & Benito, P. J. (2021). Exercise-induced muscle damage during the menstrual cycle: A systematic review and meta-analysis. Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research, 35(2), 549–561.
Key_Findings: This meta-analysis suggests that hormone fluctuations throughout the menstrual cycle affect exercise-induced muscle damage (EIMD) in terms of delayed onset muscle soreness (DOMS) and strength loss. The early follicular phase (EFP), when sex hormone concentrations (including estrogen) are lowest, showed the greatest DOMS and strength loss, suggesting women may be more vulnerable to muscle damage and require longer recovery periods during this phase. Conversely, the midluteal phase (MLP), characterized by higher estrogen and progesterone, showed the least EIMD, indicating a potential protective effect of these hormones on muscle recovery.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle and running economy in trained women
Citation: McNulty, K.L., Elliott-Sale, K.J., Dolan, E., Swinton, P.A., Ansdell, P., Goodall, S., Thomas, K., & Hicks, K.M. (2020). The Effects of Menstrual Cycle Phase on Exercise Performance in Eumenorrheic Women: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis. Sports Medicine, 50(10), 1813-1827.
Key_Findings: This systematic review and meta-analysis found that exercise performance, including endurance outcomes, may be trivially reduced during the early follicular phase of the menstrual cycle compared to other phases. However, the effect is small, and the authors conclude that general guidelines for adjusting training around the menstrual cycle are not warranted. Instead, an individualized approach based on personal experience is recommended.

Research_Topic: Female sex hormones and glycogen metabolism during endurance exercise
Citation: McNulty, K. L., Elliott-Sale, K. J., Dolan, E., Swinton, P. A., Ansdell, P., Goodall, S., Thomas, K., & Hicks, K. M. (2020). The Effects of Menstrual Cycle Phase on Exercise Performance in Eumenorrheic Women: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis. Sports Medicine, 50(10), 1813–1827.
Key_Findings: The review found that exercise performance might be trivially reduced during the early follicular phase of the menstrual cycle compared to other phases. While the study primarily focused on performance, the background section highlights that oestrogen is thought to play a role in substrate metabolism changes through increased muscle glycogen storage and increased fat utilisation, which is the underlying mechanism for the observed performance differences. The overall effect size was trivial, and the authors recommend a personalized approach due to large between-study variation and low quality of evidence in the primary studies.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle and perceived exertion in distance runners
Citation: Prado, R. C. R., Hackney, A. C., Silveira, R., Kilpatrick, M. W., Takito, M. Y., & Asano, R. Y. (2024). Effect of Menstrual Cycle Phase on Perceived Exertion During Aerobic Exercise in Eumenorrheic Women: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis. Journal of Women’s & Pelvic Health Physical Therapy, 48(2), 91-102.
Key_Findings: The meta-analysis, which included 17 studies with a total of 160 participants, concluded that menstrual cycle phases do not significantly impact the rating of perceived exertion (RPE) during continuous aerobic exercise in eumenorrheic women. This suggests that acute RPE is stable across the cycle, but the authors recommend that practitioners consider session-by-session RPE throughout the cycle for a more comprehensive training load assessment.

Research_Topic: Luteal phase and cardiovascular responses to exercise in women
Citation: Schmalenberger, K.M.; Eisenlohr-Moul, T.A.; Würth, L.; Schneider, E.; Thayer, J.F.; Ditzen, B.; Jarczok, M.N. (2019). A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Within-Person Changes in Cardiac Vagal Activity across the Menstrual Cycle: Implications for Female Health and Future Studies. J. Clin. Med., 8(11), 1946.
Key_Findings: Meta-analyses of 37 studies indicate a significant decrease in cardiac vagal activity (CVA), a marker of parasympathetic cardiovascular control, from the follicular to the luteal phase (d = −0.39). This suggests a shift toward sympathetic dominance and potentially increased cardiovascular strain during the luteal phase, which is relevant for heart rate-based training prescription. The findings highlight the need for personalized training approaches that account for these cyclical changes in autonomic regulation.

Research_Topic: Follicular phase and strength gains in female athletes
Citation: Niering, M., Wolf-Belala, N., Seifert, J., Tovar, O., Coldewey, J., Kuranda, J., & Muehlbauer, T. (2024). The Influence of Menstrual Cycle Phases on Maximal Strength Performance in Healthy Female Adults: A Systematic Review with Meta-Analysis. Sports, 12(1), 31.
Key_Findings: The meta-analysis revealed medium effects for isometric maximal strength (SMD = 0.60) and small effects for dynamic maximal strength (SMD = 0.14) favoring the late follicular phase. The early follicular phase was found to be unfavorable for all strength classes, while isokinetic strength peaked during ovulation. These findings suggest that strength training periodization based on the menstrual cycle, specifically targeting the late follicular phase, may optimize strength gains.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle and lactate threshold in runners
Citation: Meignié, A., Duclos, M., Carling, C., Orhant, E., Provost, P., Toussaint, J.-F., & Antero, J. (2021). The Effects of Menstrual Cycle Phase on Elite Athlete Performance: A Critical and Systematic Review. Frontiers in Physiology, 12, 654585.
Key_Findings: The systematic review found that studies on non-elite athletes have reported the intensity corresponding to the lactate threshold (LT) was higher during the luteal phase (LP) than the follicular phase (FP), suggesting lower blood lactate concentrations during exercise in the LP. However, the review concluded that for elite athletes, performance outcomes, including those related to endurance, appear to remain stable along the menstrual cycle, and the overall evidence is inconclusive regarding the optimal phase for performance. The authors highlight a general lack of high-quality studies on elite female athletes to draw definitive conclusions.

Research_Topic: Female hormones and mitochondrial function during exercise
Citation: Nelson, W. B., Pfeifer, B. S., Lovell, A. R., Marchant, E. D., Mitchell, B. V., Atkinson, E. L., Murphy, T. L., Poulsen, S. L., Baird, J. R. K., Hancock, C. R., & Hyldahl, R. D. (2025). Menstrual cycle influence on skeletal muscle mitochondrial respiration in humans. Physiological Reports, 13(13), e70458.
Key_Findings: The study found that mitochondrial function in skeletal muscle is subtly influenced by the menstrual cycle phase. Specifically, glutamate/malate LEAK respiration was higher in the luteal phase, while fatty acid-supported coupling efficiency and mitochondrial hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) emission were significantly higher in the early follicular phase. These findings suggest a limited, but measurable, phase-dependent effect on submaximal mitochondrial respiration and reactive oxygen species generation, which may influence training adaptations.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle and substrate utilization during marathon running
Citation: Rattley, C. A., Ansdell, P., Burgess, L. C., Felton, M., Dewhurst, S., & Neal, R. A. (2024). Influence of Oestradiol Fluctuations in the Menstrual Cycle on Respiratory Exchange Ratio at Different Exercise Intensities: A Systematic Review, Meta-Analysis and Pooled-Data Analysis. Physiologia, 4(4), 486-505.
Study_Design: Systematic Review, Meta-Analysis, and Pooled-Data Analysis
Key_Findings: The meta-analysis found no overall effect of menstrual phase on the respiratory exchange ratio (RER) during submaximal constant load exercise, suggesting no significant difference in substrate utilization. However, a higher maximal RER was observed in the follicular phase compared to the luteal phase during incremental exercise, indicating a shift towards greater fat oxidation in the luteal phase. This suggests that while overall differences are small, the high-hormone luteal phase may promote fat as a fuel source, which is beneficial for endurance events like marathon running.

Research_Topic: Iron supplementation and menstrual cycle in female endurance athletes
Citation: Pengelly, M., Pumpa, K., Pyne, D. B., & Etxebarria, N. (2025). Iron deficiency, supplementation, and sports performance in female athletes: A systematic review. Journal of Sport and Health Science, 14, 101009.
Key_Findings: Iron deficiency is highly prevalent in female athletes, partly due to iron loss during menstruation, which can be up to ~10 mg per cycle. This deficiency negatively affects endurance performance by 3-4%, a deficit that can be improved by 2-20% with daily iron supplementation (~100 mg elemental iron). The review highlights the need for female athletes to consult with a sports medicine practitioner or dietitian to manage iron status and optimize training.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle tracking and training load management in runners
Citation: Elorduy-Terrado, A.; Torres-Luque, G.; Radesca, K.; Muñoz-Andradas, G.; Saenz-Bravo, M.; Domínguez-Balmaseda, D. (2025). Evaluation the Impact of Hormonal Fluctuations During the Menstrual Cycle on the Performance of Female Athletes—Systematic Review. Muscles, 4(2), 15.
Key_Findings: Significant findings include increased flexibility during the ovulatory phase and enhanced aerobic and anaerobic capacities in the luteal phase. Additionally, the menstrual and premenstrual phases notably influenced aerobic and anaerobic capacities, performance perception, symptomatology, and exercise-induced muscle damage. Hormonal fluctuations can impact female athletes' performance, suggesting that training load management should consider cycle phase, although further research is warranted.

Research_Topic: Female athlete monitoring and menstrual cycle phase
Citation: McNulty, K. L., Elliott-Sale, K. J., Dolan, E., Swinton, P. A., & Ansdell, P. (2020). The Effects of Menstrual Cycle Phase on Exercise Performance in Eumenorrheic Women: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis. Sports Medicine, 50(10), 1813–1827.
Key_Findings: The systematic review and meta-analysis found that exercise performance might be trivially reduced during the early follicular phase (menstruation) compared to all other phases. The largest effect size was observed between the early follicular and late follicular phases, suggesting a slight performance benefit in the late follicular phase. However, due to the trivial effect size and large between-study variation, the authors recommend a personalized approach to training rather than general guidelines based on the menstrual cycle phase.

Research_Topic: Hormonal fluctuations and overtraining syndrome in female runners
Citation: Angelidi, A. M., Stefanakis, K., Chou, S. H., Valenzuela-Vallejo, L., Dipla, K., Boutari, C., Ntoskas, K., Tokmakidis, P., Kokkinos, A., Goulis, D. G., Papadaki, H. A., & Mantzoros, C. S. (2024). Relative Energy Deficiency in Sport (REDs): Endocrine Manifestations, Pathophysiology and Treatments. Endocrine Reviews, 45(5), 676–708.
Key_Findings: Relative Energy Deficiency in Sport (REDs), which is caused by low energy availability (LEA), is the modern and comprehensive framework that encompasses the hormonal dysfunctions previously associated with overtraining syndrome in female athletes. LEA leads to a broad spectrum of maladaptive changes, including neuroendocrine dysregulation (e.g., suppressed GnRH pulsatility, leading to menstrual dysfunction) and compromised bone health. The review emphasizes that nonpharmacological, behavioral, and lifestyle modifications targeting the underlying energy deficit are the primary treatment, with novel therapies focusing on molecules like leptin and the activin-follistatin-inhibin axis as potential future targets.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle and heat stress responses in female athletes
Citation: Giersch, G. E. W., Morrissey, M. C., Katch, R. K., Colburn, A. T., Sims, S. T., Stachenfeld, N. S., & Casa, D. J. (2020). Menstrual cycle and thermoregulation during exercise in the heat: A systematic review and meta-analysis. Journal of Science and Medicine in Sport, 23(12), 1134-1140.
Key_Findings: The systematic review and meta-analysis found that initial (pre-exercise) and post-exercise internal body temperature were significantly greater in the luteal phase compared to the follicular phase. This suggests a higher thermal load in the luteal phase, which could potentially impair performance in the heat. However, no significant differences were found in mean skin temperature, sweat rate, or exercise heart rate across the menstrual phases.

Research_Topic: Estradiol and bone health in female distance runners
Citation: Aalberg, K., Stavem, K., Norheim, F., Russell, M. B., & Chaibi, A. (2021). Effect of oral and transdermal oestrogen therapy on bone mineral density in functional hypothalamic amenorrhoea: a systematic review and meta-analysis. BMJ Open Sport & Exercise Medicine, 7(3), e001112.
Key_Findings: The systematic review and meta-analysis of nine randomized controlled trials found that pooled results for all oestrogen therapies (oral contraceptives, conjugated oestrogens, and transdermal estradiol) showed no significant overall effect on bone mineral density (BMD) in premenopausal women with functional hypothalamic amenorrhoea (FHA). However, the literature suggests that transdermal estradiol may increase lumbar BMD, and it is recommended as a second-line comanagement strategy to optimize bone health in amenorrhoeic athletes, while oral contraceptives should not be used for this purpose. The primary strategy remains the restoration of energy balance and weight.

Research_Topic: Carbohydrate metabolism across menstrual cycle phases in female endurance athletes
Citation: Oosthuyse, T., Strauss, J. A., & Hackney, A. C. (2023). Understanding the female athlete: molecular mechanisms underpinning menstrual phase differences in exercise metabolism. European Journal of Applied Physiology, 123(3), 423–450.
Study_Design: Invited Review and Synthesis of Molecular Mechanisms
Sample_Size: Multiple studies (review of molecular mechanisms and meta-analyses)
Key_Findings: Estrogen (E2) signaling maximizes fat oxidation capacity in the late follicular and mid-luteal phases, which is favorable for endurance exercise at low-to-moderate intensities. However, E2-dominant suppression of gluconeogenic gene expression can nullify E2-promoted plasma glucose uptake, suggesting that carbohydrate ingestion is necessary to maintain glucose availability during these phases. Progesterone (P4) increases protein catabolism during the luteal phase, which has implications for recovery and muscle strengthening.

Research_Topic: Protein requirements and menstrual cycle in female runners
Citation: Mercer, D.; Convit, L.; Condo, D.; Carr, A. J.; Hamilton, D. L.; Slater, G.; Snipe, R. M. J. (2020). Protein Requirements of Pre-Menopausal Female Athletes: Systematic Literature Review. Nutrients, 12(11), 3527.
Key_Findings: The systematic review found that the estimated average protein requirement (EAR) for pre-menopausal female athletes is similar across exercise types, ranging from 1.28–1.63 g/kg/day. The authors concluded that there is currently insufficient research to determine the influence of the menstrual cycle phase or hormonal contraceptive use on protein requirements. However, pre- and post-exercise intakes of 0.32–0.38 g/kg were found to demonstrate beneficial physiological responses.

Research_Topic: Hydration needs and hormonal fluctuations in female athletes
Citation: Giersch, G. E. W., Charkoudian, N., Stearns, R. L., & Casa, D. J. (2020). Fluid Balance and Hydration Considerations for Women: Review and Future Directions. Sports Medicine, 50(2), 253–261.
Key_Findings: Female reproductive hormonal profiles over the course of the menstrual cycle have significant influences on thermoregulatory and volume regulatory physiology, with the high-hormone (luteal) phase being associated with a higher core body temperature and potentially greater fluid retention. The review highlights that while dehydration's impact on performance is clear, the interaction between hormonal influences and dehydration is poorly understood, necessitating further research to develop optimal hydration strategies for female athletes. The authors suggest that the hormonal fluctuations may affect thirst and volume regulatory hormones, which could influence hydration status and exercise performance.

Research_Topic: Magnesium supplementation and menstrual cycle symptoms in athletes
Citation: Yaralizadeh, M., Nezamivand-Chegini, S., Najar, S., Namjoyan, F., & Abedi, P. (2024). Effectiveness of Magnesium on Menstrual Symptoms Among Dysmenorrheal College Students: A Randomized Controlled Trial. International Journal of Women's Health and Reproduction Sciences, 12(2), 70-76.
Key_Findings: Both 150 mg and 300 mg doses of magnesium stearate significantly reduced all symptoms of dysmenorrhea in college students compared to a placebo. The 300 mg dose was more effective in decreasing symptoms such as cramps, headache, back pain, depression, and irritability. This suggests magnesium supplementation is an effective non-pharmacological intervention for menstrual symptoms that can interfere with daily activities and training.

Research_Topic: Calcium and vitamin D requirements across menstrual cycle in runners
Citation: De Souza, M. J., Ricker, E. A., Mallinson, R. J., Allaway, H. C. M., Koltun, K. J., Strock, N. C. A., Gibbs, J. C., Kuruppumullage Don, P., & Williams, N. I. (2022). Bone mineral density in response to increased energy intake in exercising women with oligomenorrhea/amenorrhea: the REFUEL randomized controlled trial. The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition, 115(6), 1457–1472.
Sample_Size: n=76 women (40 in intervention, 36 in control)
Key_Findings: The 12-month randomized controlled trial demonstrated that increasing energy intake in exercising women with menstrual dysfunction led to a greater likelihood of menses resumption, but it did not improve areal bone mineral density (aBMD) compared to the control group. Both groups experienced a decrease in femoral neck and total hip aBMD over the study period, suggesting that the intervention's magnitude or duration was insufficient to improve bone health, despite the inclusion of calcium and vitamin D supplementation as part of the intervention. This highlights the critical role of energy availability over micronutrient supplementation alone for bone health recovery in this population.

Research_Topic: Omega-3 fatty acids and inflammation in female endurance athletes
Citation: Loss, L. C., Benini, D., de Lima-e-Silva, F. X., Möller, G. B., & da Silva, J. C. (2022). Effects of omega-3 supplementation on muscle damage after resistance exercise in young women: a randomized placebo-controlled trial. Nutrition and Health, 28(3), 425–432.
Key_Findings: This randomized controlled trial found that a three-day post-exercise supplementation of 3200 mg/day of omega-3 fish oil provided no additional benefit over a placebo in reducing muscle soreness or improving muscle strength recovery in healthy young women following a balanced diet. The study did not specifically investigate the menstrual cycle, but its focus on young women and muscle recovery is relevant to female athletes. The results suggest that short-term, post-exercise omega-3 supplementation may not be sufficient to mitigate exercise-induced muscle damage markers in this population.

Research_Topic: Caffeine and performance across menstrual cycle phases
Citation: Grgic, J., & Varovic, D. (2024). Moderators of Caffeine’s Effects on Jumping Performance in Females: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis. Journal of the American Nutrition Association, 43(1), 92-100.
Key_Findings: Caffeine ingestion is ergogenic for vertical jumping performance in females, with the magnitude of the effect being the largest in the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle. Specifically, the ergogenic effect was significantly greater in the follicular phase (g: 0.52) compared to the luteal phase (g: 0.24) or when the phase was not specified. This suggests that female athletes may experience the greatest performance benefit from caffeine supplementation during the follicular phase.

Research_Topic: Creatine supplementation in female athletes and menstrual cycle
Citation: Tam, R., Mitchell, L., & Forsyth, A. (2025). Does Creatine Supplementation Enhance Performance in Active Females? A Systematic Review. Nutrients, 17(2), 238.
Sample_Size: Multiple studies (systematic review of 27 studies with n=514 women)
Key_Findings: The review found inconclusive evidence regarding the effectiveness of creatine supplementation on performance in active females, with most studies showing no benefit compared to placebo. The authors highlight that the small evidence base and insufficient consideration of female-specific physiology, particularly the menstrual cycle, limit definitive conclusions. They emphasize the critical need for future high-quality research that appropriately classifies participants' reproductive status and standardizes testing to better understand creatine's effects in women.

Research_Topic: Electrolyte balance and luteal phase in female runners
Citation: Rodriguez-Giustiniani, P., Rodriguez-Sanchez, N., & Galloway, S. D. R. (2022). Fluid and electrolyte balance considerations for female athletes. European Journal of Sport Science, 22(5), 697-708.
Key_Findings: This systematic review found that while oestrogen and progesterone fluctuations across the menstrual cycle have independent roles in regulating fluid and electrolyte balance, these actions do not appear to consistently influence fluid retention, plasma volume changes, or electrolyte losses at rest or during exercise. The review concludes that mean responses largely show no effect on fluid and electrolyte balance, but acknowledges that individuals with high hormonal fluctuations may experience disturbances. Further research is warranted to explore these individual variations and the complex interactions between oestrogen and progesterone.

Research_Topic: Pre-menstrual nutritional strategies for female athletes
Citation: Larrosa, M., Gil-Izquierdo, A., González-Rodríguez, L. G., Muñoz Alférez, M. J., San Juan, A. F., Sánchez-Gómez, Á., Calvo-Ayuso, N., Ramos-Álvarez, J. J., Fernández-Lázaro, D., Lopez-Grueso, R., López-León, I., Moreno-Lara, J., Domínguez-Balmaseda, D., Illescas-Quiroga, R., Cuenca, E., López, T., Montoya, J. J., Rodrigues-de-Souza, D. P., Carrillo-Alvarez, E., Casado, A., Rodriguez-Doñate, B., Porta-Oliva, M., Santiago, C., Iturriaga, T., De Lucas, B., García Solaesa, Á., Montero-López, M. P., Benítez De Gracia, E., Veiga-Herreros, P., Muñoz-López, A., Orantes-Gonzalez, E., Barbero-Alvarez, J. C., Cabeza-Ruiz, R., Carnero-Diaz, Á., Sospedra, I., Fernández-Galván, L. M., Martínez-Sanz, J. M., Martín-Almena, F. J., Pérez, M., Guerra-Hernández, E. J., López-Samanes, Á., Sánchez-Oliver, A. J., & Domínguez, R. (2024). Nutritional Strategies for Optimizing Health, Sports Performance, and Recovery for Female Athletes and Other Physically Active Women: A Systematic Review. Nutrition Reviews, 83(3), e1068.
Key_Findings: The luteal phase, which precedes the pre-menstrual phase, is characterized by hormonal shifts that decrease carbohydrate sensitivity and increase protein catabolism, potentially leading to insulin and anabolic resistance. The review suggests that nutritional strategies should focus on counteracting these effects, with general recommendations including high carbohydrate intake for glycogen-depleting activities and 5–6 protein meals of over 25g each to support muscle anabolism. While not specific to the pre-menstrual phase, the findings highlight the need for adjusted macronutrient intake during the high-hormone phase to mitigate performance detriments and maintain body composition.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle and gastrointestinal issues in female distance runners
Citation: Kelly, M. R., Emerson, D. M., McDermott, B. P., Atkins, W. C., Butts, C. L., Mark, R., Troyanos, C., Duckett, A., & Siedlik, J. (2023). Gastrointestinal cell injury and perceived symptoms after running the Boston Marathon. Frontiers in Physiology, 14, 1268306.
Sample_Size: n=21 women (out of n=40 total runners)
Key_Findings: Female runners were asked about menstrual cycle regularity, but the study did not find a significant correlation between menstrual cycle regularity and post-race GI symptoms. The study confirmed that GI symptoms are highly individualized and that GI cell injury (I-FABP) and perceived GI distress symptoms are common after marathon running in both male and female runners. The study suggests that pre-existing conditions and risk factors, rather than the menstrual cycle, may be more influential on GI distress in this population.

Research_Topic: Female athlete nutrition periodization and hormonal phases
Citation: Larrosa, M., Gil-Izquierdo, A., González-Rodríguez, L. G., Muñoz Alférez, M. J., San Juan, A. F., Sánchez-Gómez, Á., Calvo-Ayuso, N., Ramos-Álvarez, J. J., Fernández-Lázaro, D., Lopez-Grueso, R., López-León, I., Moreno-Lara, J., Domínguez-Balmaseda, D., Illescas-Quiroga, R., Cuenca, E., López, T., Montoya, J. J., Rodrigues-de-Souza, D. P., Carrillo-Alvarez, E., Casado, A., Rodriguez-Doñate, B., Porta-Oliva, M., Santiago, C., Iturriaga, T., De Lucas, B., García Solaesa, Á., Montero-López, M. D. P., Benítez De Gracia, E., Veiga-Herreros, P., Muñoz-López, A., Orantes-Gonzalez, E., Barbero-Alvarez, J. C., Cabeza-Ruiz, R., Carnero-Diaz, Á., Sospedra, I., Fernández-Galván, L. M., Martínez-Sanz, J. M., Martín-Almena, F. J., Pérez, M., Guerra-Hernández, E. J., López-Samanes, Á., Sánchez-Oliver, A. J., & Domínguez, R. (2025). Nutritional Strategies for Optimizing Health, Sports Performance, and Recovery for Female Athletes and Other Physically Active Women: A Systematic Review. Nutrition Reviews, 83(3), e1068-e1089.
Key_Findings: The review found that while specific nutritional recommendations for female athletes are scarce, general strategies like high-carbohydrate diets for glycogen depletion activities and frequent protein intake (5-6 meals >25g) are beneficial. The authors noted a moderate risk of bias in the included studies, often due to insufficient control for the hormonal phase of the menstrual cycle, highlighting a significant gap in the evidence base for cycle-specific nutrition periodization. Supplements like caffeine, nitric oxide precursors, and β-alanine may positively influence performance and health.

Research_Topic: Vitamin B complex and energy metabolism in menstruating athletes
Citation: Larrosa, M., Gil-Izquierdo, A., González-Rodríguez, L. G., Muñoz Alférez, M. J., San Juan, A. F., Sánchez-Gómez, Á., Calvo-Ayuso, N., Ramos-Álvarez, J. J., Fernández-Lázaro, D., Lopez-Grueso, R., López-León, I., Moreno-Lara, J., Domínguez-Balmaseda, D., Illescas-Quiroga, R., Cuenca, E., López, T., Montoya, J. J., Rodrigues-de-Souza, D. P., Carrillo-Alvarez, E., Casado, A., Rodriguez-Doñate, B., Porta-Oliva, M., Santiago, C., Iturriaga, T., De Lucas, B., García Solaesa, Á., Montero-López, M. P., Benítez De Gracia, E., Veiga-Herreros, P., Muñoz-López, A., Orantes-Gonzalez, E., Barbero-Alvarez, J. C., Cabeza-Ruiz, R., Carnero-Diaz, Á., Sospedra, I., Fernández-Galván, L. M., Martínez-Sanz, J. M., Martín-Almena, F. J., Pérez, M., Guerra-Hernández, E. J., López-Samanes, Á., Sánchez-Oliver, A. J., & Domínguez, R. (2025). Nutritional Strategies for Optimizing Health, Sports Performance, and Recovery for Female Athletes and Other Physically Active Women: A Systematic Review. *Nutrition Reviews*, *83*(3), e1068–e1089.
Key_Findings: The systematic review, which included 71 studies, found that while B vitamins are critical for energy metabolism, supplementation with folate and vitamin B12 does not provide additional performance improvements in female athletes who are not deficient. The review highlighted that micronutrient deficiencies, including B vitamins, are a risk for female athletes, and addressing these deficiencies is key to optimizing health and performance. The study noted that insufficient description of how the hormonal phase during the menstrual cycle was controlled for was a common limitation in the included studies.

Research_Topic: Antioxidant needs across menstrual cycle in endurance athletes
Citation: Mano, Y., Kato, A., Fukuda, N., Yamada, K., & Yanagimoto, K. (2022). Influence of Ingestion of Eicosapentaenoic Acid-Rich Fish Oil on Oxidative Stress at the Menstrual Phase: A Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Parallel-Group Trial. Women's Health Reports, 3(1), 643–651.
Key_Findings: EPA-rich fish oil supplementation significantly decreased markers of oxidative stress (d-ROMs) and increased potential antioxidant capacity during the follicular phase in female athletes. During the menstrual phase, the supplementation also decreased d-ROMs, suggesting an active involvement in antioxidant function during both low and high hormone phases. This indicates that EPA supplementation may be a beneficial nutritional strategy to support the redox balance in female athletes across the menstrual cycle.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle and appetite regulation in female runners
Citation: Tucker, J. A. L., McCarthy, S. F., Bornath, D. P. D., Khoja, J. S., & Hazell, T. J. (2025). The Effect of the Menstrual Cycle on Energy Intake: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis. Nutrition Reviews, 83(3), e866–e876.
Key_Findings: The meta-analysis found a statistically significant increase in energy intake during the luteal phase (LP) compared to the follicular phase (FP), with a crude average difference of 168 kcal per day. This suggests that nutritional strategies for female athletes should account for this increased energy demand in the LP to maintain energy balance and support training adaptations. However, the authors noted repeated methodological inconsistencies across the included studies, highlighting the need for standardized best practices in future research.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle and gut microbiome in female endurance athletes
Citation: Brito, J., Grosicki, G. J., Robinson, A. T., Coburn, J. W., Costa, P. B., Holmes, K. E., Lyon, G., Hakonsson, Z., Conti, F., & Galpin, A. J. (2025). Hormonal birth control is associated with altered gut microbiota β-diversity in physically active females across the menstrual cycle: a pilot trial. Journal of Applied Physiology, 138(3), 739-745.
Sample_Size: n=24 women (12 HBC users, 12 non-HBC users)
Key_Findings: This pilot cohort study found that physically active females using hormonal birth control (HBC) had a distinct gut microbiota profile (altered β-diversity) compared to non-HBC users, irrespective of the menstrual cycle phase. Furthermore, seven taxa linked to short-chain fatty acid (SCFA) production were less abundant in the HBC group, suggesting that hormonal contraception may influence gut microbial composition with potential downstream effects on metabolism and performance. The study highlights the need for further experimental research to confirm these associations and explore their implications for female athletes.

Research_Topic: Zinc and copper status across menstrual cycle in runners
Citation: Singh, A., Deuster, P. A., & Moser, P. B. (1990). Zinc and copper status in women by physical activity and menstrual status. The Journal of Sports Medicine and Physical Fitness, 30(1), 29-36.
Sample_Size: n=72 women (33 eumenorrheic runners, 12 amenorrheic runners, 19 eumenorrheic nonrunners, 8 amenorrheic nonrunners)
Key_Findings: No indices of zinc or copper status differed as a function of menstrual status in the runners. However, chronic exercise (running) appeared to induce a a redistribution of zinc and copper, with runners showing lower plasma zinc but higher erythrocyte zinc and higher plasma copper but lower erythrocyte copper compared to nonrunners. This suggests that while the menstrual cycle may not be the primary driver of status changes, the training itself significantly alters trace element distribution.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle phase and nutrient timing for female athletes
Citation: Helm, M.M., McGinnis, G.R., & Basu, A. (2021). Impact of Nutrition-Based Interventions on Athletic Performance during Menstrual Cycle Phases: A Review. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 18(12), 6294.
Key_Findings: This critical focused review found that while research is scarce, some nutrition-based interventions show promise for specific menstrual phases. Promising interventions for the follicular phase included CES beverages and blackcurrant extract, while the luteal phase showed potential benefits from Montmorency cherry concentrate and caffeine. The authors conclude that cycle-specific nutrition-based interventions, informed by an understanding of menstrual physiology, can potentially improve athletic performance, though current evidence is limited and often based on studies testing interventions in only one phase.

Research_Topic: Plant-based diets and menstrual cycle in female endurance athletes
Citation: Isenmann, E., Trojak, I., Lesch, A., Schalla, J., Havers, T., Diel, P., & Geisler, S. (2024). The influence of a vegan diet on body composition, performance and the menstrual cycle in young, recreationally trained women– a 12-week controlled trial. Journal of the International Society of Sports Nutrition, 21(1), 2413961.
Study_Design: Controlled Trial (Pre-post design with 4-week omnivorous phase and 8-week vegan intervention)
Key_Findings: The 8-week vegan phase resulted in a significant decrease in relative protein intake and a slight decrease in skeletal muscle mass, suggesting implementation difficulties for recreationally trained women. No clear effects on hormone concentrations or the menstrual cycle were observed during the study period. The authors caution that the results cannot be generalized to well-trained female athletes or long-term effects.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle and mood in female endurance athletes
Citation: Paludo, A. C., Paravlic, A., Dvořáková, K., & Gimunová, M. (2022). The Effect of Menstrual Cycle on Perceptual Responses in Athletes: A Systematic Review With Meta-Analysis. Frontiers in Psychology, 13, 926854.
Key_Findings: The systematic review and meta-analysis found that while perceived exertion did not significantly differ between menstrual cycle phases, mood disturbance was reported to increase in the pre-menstrual phase compared to mid-cycle in some studies. Overall, a "favorable" subjective response, including mood, was noticed when ovarian hormones were at higher concentration levels, suggesting that individual perceptual responses are affected by the menstrual cycle. The authors conclude that different perceptual variables and methodological approaches limit the generalization of the conclusion.

Research_Topic: Sleep quality across menstrual cycle phases in female runners
Citation: Koikawa N, Takami Y, Kawasaki Y, et al. (2020). Changes in the objective measures of sleep between the initial nights of menses and the nights during the midfollicular phase of the menstrual cycle in collegiate female athletes. Journal of Clinical Sleep Medicine, 16(10), 1745–1751.
Key_Findings: The study found that collegiate female athletes with regular menstrual cycles experienced significantly reduced total sleep time and prolonged sleep onset latency during the second night of menses compared to the midfollicular phase. Sleep efficiency was also significantly reduced on the first night of menses. Furthermore, participants with menstrual symptoms or concerns about sanitary products spent a lower percentage of time in deep sleep during menses, suggesting that sleep is disturbed during menses even in young, healthy female athletes.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle and motivation for training in female athletes
Citation: Paludo, A. C., Paravlic, A., Dvořáková, K., & Gimunová, M. (2022). The Effect of Menstrual Cycle on Perceptual Responses in Athletes: A Systematic Review With Meta-Analysis. Frontiers in Psychology, 13, 926854.
Key_Findings: The systematic review found that some perceptual responses, including motivation and competitiveness, showed statistically significant changes during the menstrual cycle, with better outcomes in the ovulatory phase compared to the follicular and luteal phases. The authors suggest that a "favorable" subjective response is noticed when ovarian hormones (estrogen and progesterone) present an increase in concentration levels. However, the meta-analysis on perceived effort showed no significant difference between the phases.

Research_Topic: Premenstrual syndrome and athletic performance in runners
Citation: Kubica, C., Ketelhut, S., & Nigg, C. R. (2023). Effects of a training intervention tailored to the menstrual cycle on endurance performance, recovery and well-being in female recreational runners – A randomized-controlled pilot study. Current Issues in Sport Science (CISS), 8(2), 026.
Key_Findings: An 8-week polarized running training, whether block-periodized or individually adapted to the menstrual cycle (MC), was equally effective in improving VO2peak in eumenorrheic female runners. The study found no additional benefits of an MC-adapted training on recovery and premenstrual symptoms in recreational runners. However, the authors noted that limitations in the pilot study design, such as calendar-based cycle tracking, may have obscured potential benefits.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle and stress responses in female endurance athletes
Citation: Paludo, A. C., Paravlic, A., Dvořáková, K., & Gimunová, M. (2022). The Effect of Menstrual Cycle on Perceptual Responses in Athletes: A Systematic Review With Meta-Analysis. Frontiers in Psychology, 13, 926854.
Key_Findings: This systematic review and meta-analysis found that the menstrual cycle phase generally does not affect perceived exertion, stress, or muscle soreness in athletes. However, some perceptual responses like motivation and competitiveness were higher during the ovulatory phase, while mood disturbances and menstrual symptoms were higher pre-menstruation and during the menstrual phase. These findings suggest that while physical performance perception may be stable, psychological and symptomatic factors vary, which could inform cycle-synced training adjustments.

Research_Topic: Recovery strategies and menstrual cycle phase in female athletes
Citation: Schlie, J., Krassowski, V., & Schmidt, A. (2025). Effects of menstrual cycle phases on athletic performance and related physiological outcomes: a systematic review of studies using high methodological standards. Journal of Applied Physiology, 139(3), Pages TBD.
Key_Findings: This systematic review of studies with high methodological standards found that 58% of the included studies reported significant menstrual cycle phase effects on at least one performance-related outcome, though the direction and magnitude varied. The early follicular phase was occasionally identified as unfavorable for V̇o2max and peak power. The study highlights the need for more research on recovery strategies, as the topic is intertwined with performance and physiological outcomes.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle and perceived effort during marathon training
Citation: Paludo, A. C., Paravlic, A., Dvořáková, K., & Gimunová, M. (2022). The Effect of Menstrual Cycle on Perceptual Responses in Athletes: A Systematic Review With Meta-Analysis. Frontiers in Psychology, 13, 926854.
Key_Findings: The meta-analysis found no significant difference in the level of perceived exertion (RPE) between the early follicular phase (days 1–5) and the mid-luteal phase (days 19–24) in athletes. However, the review noted that other perceptual responses, such as motivation and competitiveness, may be higher during ovulation, while mood disturbance and fatigue are often worse pre-menstruation or during menstruation. This suggests that while the physical perception of effort may be stable, the psychological and emotional experience of training can fluctuate across the cycle.

Research_Topic: Mental health and menstrual irregularities in female distance runners
Citation: Carson, T. L., West, B. T., Sonneville, K., Zernicke, R. F., Clarke, P., Harlow, S., & Karvonen-Gutierrez, C. (2023). Identifying latent classes of Relative Energy Deficiency in Sport (RED-S) consequences in a sample of collegiate female cross country runners. British Journal of Sports Medicine, 57(3), 153.
Sample_Size: n=211 current NCAA Division I female cross country runners
Key_Findings: The study identified a high burden of menstrual disturbance in NCAA Division I cross country runners, with three distinct classes of Relative Energy Deficiency in Sport (RED-S) consequences. The most severe class was characterized by a very high probability of anxiety alongside a high burden of menstrual disturbance, bone injury, and gastrointestinal concern. This highlights a strong link between mental health (anxiety) and physiological consequences (menstrual irregularities) in this population.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle and body image in female athletes
Citation: Ravi, S., Waller, B., Valtonen, M., Villberg, J., Vasankari, T., Parkkari, J., Heinonen, O. J., Alanko, L., Savonen, K., Vanhala, M., Selänne, H., Kokko, S., & Kujala, U. M. (2021). Menstrual dysfunction and body weight dissatisfaction among Finnish young athletes and non‐athletes. Scandinavian Journal of Medicine & Science in Sports, 31(2), 405–417.
Key_Findings: This longitudinal cohort study found that young female athletes had a smaller tendency to experience body weight dissatisfaction compared to their non-athletic peers, although about one-fifth of athletes still reported dissatisfaction. Menstrual dysfunction (MD) was frequent among athletes (38.7% in young adulthood) and was associated with lower BMI in adolescence, suggesting a link between body composition, MD, and body image. The findings highlight the need for early focus on MD causes in an athlete's career, as MD was a longitudinal predictor from adolescence to adulthood.

Research_Topic: Sleep architecture and hormonal fluctuations in female athletes
Citation: Miles, K. H., Clark, B., Fowler, P. M., Miller, J., & Pumpa, K. L. (2022). What are the sleep characteristics of elite female athletes? A systematic review with meta-analysis. Biology of Sport, 39(3), 751–763.
Key_Findings: The review found that while the impact on sleep architecture itself is currently unclear, evidence suggests that hormonal changes throughout the menstrual cycle and the use of exogenous oral contraceptives may influence sleep in female athletes. The authors highlight the limited control for menstrual cycle phase in the current body of research and recommend that future investigations consider menstrual cycle phase and contraceptive use to improve the interpretation of findings and allow for tailored support. The meta-analysis of 38 studies found that female athletes achieve satisfactory objective sleep quantity and quality during habitual periods, but experience sleep disturbances pre- and post-situational challenges.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle and training adherence in recreational female runners
Citation: Paludo, A. C., Paravlic, A., Dvořáková, K., & Gimunová, M. (2022). The Effect of Menstrual Cycle on Perceptual Responses in Athletes: A Systematic Review With Meta-Analysis. Frontiers in Psychology, 13, 926854.
Key_Findings: This systematic review and meta-analysis found that some perceptual responses, such as motivation and competitiveness, are better during the ovulatory phase, while negative responses like mood disturbance and menstrual symptoms are worse pre-menstruation and during menstruation. The findings suggest that while perceived effort is not significantly affected, the fluctuations in psychological and symptomatic factors could influence training adherence and quality across the cycle.

Research_Topic: Mindfulness and menstrual cycle symptoms in female athletes
Citation: SantaBarbara KL, Helms ER, Stewart TI, Armour MJ, Harris NK. (2024). A Randomized Crossover Pilot Trial on the Influence of a Daily Mindfulness Yoga Practice on Menstrual Cycle Symptoms, Measures of Well-Being, and Training Perception in Athletic Women. International Journal of Yoga Therapy, 34(2024), Article 17.
Key_Findings: A 10-minute daily yoga practice (mindfulness-based) was significantly associated with changes in menstrual cycle symptoms, mitigating bloating, low-back pain, menstrual cramps, and stress perception in athletic women. The intervention also stabilized perceived athletic performance metrics across the menstrual cycle.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle and pain perception in female endurance athletes
Citation: Paludo AC, Paravlic A, Dvořáková K and Gimunová M. (2022). The Effect of Menstrual Cycle on Perceptual Responses in Athletes: A Systematic Review With Meta-Analysis. Frontiers in Psychology, 13, 926854.
Key_Findings: The systematic review and meta-analysis found that perceptual responses such as muscle soreness, stress, and perceived effort were not significantly affected by the menstrual cycle phase in female athletes. However, positive responses like motivation and competitiveness were better during ovulation, while negative responses (mood disturbance, menstrual symptoms) were exacerbated during pre-menstruation and menstruation. This suggests that while pain perception may be stable, psychological and symptomatic factors should be considered for training periodization.

Research_Topic: Cognitive performance across menstrual cycle in female athletes
Citation: Ronca, F., Watson, E., Metcalf, I., & Tari, B. (2025). Menstrual Cycle and Athletic Status Interact to Influence Symptoms, Mood, and Cognition in Females. Sports Medicine - Open, 11(1), 104.
Key_Findings: This study found that cognitive performance, specifically reaction time and error rates, fluctuated across the menstrual cycle in female athletes, with performance being best during ovulation. However, these fluctuations were mild and individual, and athletic level had a more significant impact on cognitive performance than the menstrual cycle phase.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle and self-efficacy in female runners
Citation: Morse, C. I., Hearn, J., Holmes, P. S., & Kolić, P. (2024). Physical Activity Avoidance During Menstruation—The Role of Coping and Self-Efficacy. Women in Sport and Physical Activity Journal, 32(1), wspaj.2024-0054.
Key_Findings: Compared with nonavoiders and adapters, avoiders had lower self-efficacy for exercise. Avoiders of physical activity during menstruation do so with more severe symptoms, a less positive attitude, and lower self-efficacy. Adapters, despite similar symptoms to avoiders, continue to exercise, underpinned by a higher self-efficacy for exercise.

Research_Topic: Massage therapy and menstrual cycle recovery in female athletes
Citation: Bunpean, A., Chantarapon, P., Salaeh, N., & E-tae, N. (2025). The Effectiveness of Traction Massage Combined with Herbal Compress for Relieving Menstrual Cramps: A Randomized Controlled Trial. International Journal of Therapeutic Massage & Bodywork, 18(4), 20–30.
Key_Findings: A randomized controlled trial demonstrated that a combination of 10-minute traction massage and a 15-minute herbal compress significantly reduced the intensity of menstrual cramps and associated symptoms like fatigue and dizziness. The intervention was more effective than health-care advice alone in a sample of women experiencing primary dysmenorrhea. This suggests massage can be an effective recovery strategy for menstrual-related discomfort.

Research_Topic: Compression garments and recovery across menstrual phases
Citation: Leabeater, A., James, L., & Driller, M. (2022). The influence of compression garments on recovery during a triathlon training camp: a pilot study. Journal of Science & Cycling, 11(3), 56-66.
Key_Findings: This pilot study provides preliminary evidence that lower-body compression garments may reduce perceived stress and muscle soreness during an intense training block in triathletes. However, due to the very small sample of female participants and lack of specific analysis across menstrual phases, no conclusions can be drawn regarding the influence of compression on recovery across the menstrual cycle.

Research_Topic: Cold water immersion and menstrual cycle in female athletes
Citation: Wellauer, V., Clijsen, R., Bianchi, G., Riggi, E., & Hohenauer, E. (2025). No acceleration of recovery from exercise-induced muscle damage after cold or hot water immersion in women: A randomised controlled trial. PLoS ONE, 20(5), e0322416.
Key_Findings: This study found that while cold water immersion (CWI) and hot water immersion (HWI) had distinct acute physiological effects after exercise in women, neither method accelerated recovery compared to a passive control group. Over a 72-hour follow-up period, there were no significant improvements in subjective or objective recovery markers such as muscle soreness or strength. These results suggest that for female athletes, the choice between CWI and HWI may not significantly impact long-term recovery from exercise-induced muscle damage.

Research_Topic: Active recovery strategies and hormonal phases in female runners
Citation: Silva, A. F., Trybulska, R., Trybek, G., Moska, W., Aidar, F. J., & González-Fernández, F. T. (2025). Impact of The Menstrual Cycle on Physical Recovery after Small-Sided Games: A Crossover Study in Women's Soccer Players. Journal of Sports Science and Medicine, 24(2), 532-542.
Key_Findings: The study found that neuromuscular fatigue (Reactive Strength Index) and inflammatory response (Interleukin-6) to exercise are modulated by the menstrual cycle phase. Specifically, the mid-luteal phase was associated with significantly lower RSI and higher IL-6, suggesting a reduced recovery capacity during this hormonal phase. These findings imply that training and recovery strategies should be periodized to account for the mid-luteal phase's increased vulnerability to fatigue and inflammation.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle and training monotony in female endurance athletes
Citation: Cristina-Souza, G., Santos-Mariano, A. C., Souza-Rodrigues, C. C., Osiecki, R., Silva, S. F., Lima-Silva, A. E., & De Oliveira, F. R. (2019). Menstrual cycle alters training strain, monotony, and technical training length in young. Journal of Sports Sciences, 37(16), 1824-1830.
Key_Findings: The study found that training monotony and strain were significantly higher during the follicular phase compared to the ovulatory phase in young female athletes. Furthermore, menstrual cycle symptoms were exacerbated during the follicular phase, suggesting a need for adjusted training programming. These findings indicate that monitoring the menstrual cycle can provide important feedback for avoiding excessive strain and monotony during specific phases.

Research_Topic: High-intensity interval training and menstrual cycle in female runners
Citation: McNulty, K. L., Elliott-Sale, K. J., Dolan, E., Swinton, P. A., Ansdell, P., Goodall, S., Thomas, K., & Hicks, K. M. (2020). The effects of menstrual cycle phase on exercise performance in eumenorrheic women: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Sports Medicine, 50, 1813–1827.
Key_Findings: The systematic review and meta-analysis found that exercise performance is only trivially reduced during the early follicular phase of the menstrual cycle compared to all other phases. However, due to the trivial effect size, large between-study variation, and low quality of the included studies, the authors conclude that general guidelines for periodizing training across the menstrual cycle cannot be formed. Instead, a personalized approach based on an individual's response to exercise performance across the cycle is recommended.

Research_Topic: Strength training periodization and menstrual cycle in female athletes
Citation: McNulty, K. L., Elliott-Sale, K. J., Dolan, E., Swinton, P. A., Ansdell, P., Goodall, S., Thomas, K., & Hicks, K. M. (2020). The Effects of Menstrual Cycle Phase on Exercise Performance in Eumenorrheic Women: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis. Sports Medicine, 50(10), 1813–1827.
Key_Findings: The meta-analysis, which included strength-based outcomes, found a trivial reduction in exercise performance during the early follicular phase compared to all other phases. Due to the trivial effect size and high between-study variation, the authors conclude that general guidelines for menstrual cycle-based periodization cannot be formed. They recommend a personalized approach based on each individual's response to exercise performance across the menstrual cycle.

Research_Topic: Plyometric training and hormonal phases in female runners
Citation: Hutson, M. J., O’Donnell, E., Petherick, E., Brooke-Wavell, K., & Blagrove, R. C. (2021). Incidence of bone stress injury is greater in competitive female distance runners with menstrual disturbances independent of participation in plyometric training. Journal of Sports Sciences, 39(22), 2558-2566.
Key_Findings: The study found that the incidence rate of bone stress injury (BSI) was 2.25 times greater in oligo/amenorrhoeic runners compared to eumenorrhoeic runners. While plyometric training (PT) appeared to reduce the BSI incidence rate in oligo/amenorrhoeic runners, the overall effect of PT was non-significant, suggesting that PT alone may not be sufficient to mitigate the risk associated with menstrual disturbances. The primary conclusion is that avoiding menstrual disturbances and prolonged periods of low energy availability is critical for BSI prevention in competitive female distance runners.

Research_Topic: Running biomechanics across menstrual cycle phases
Citation: Golden, D., Moore, E. M., Weltman, A., Statuta, S., & Hertel, J. (2025). Gait Biomechanics Among Female Endurance Runners: Comparing Days With and Without Menstrual Cycle–Related Symptoms. Journal of Athletic Training, 60(11), 783.
Sample_Size: n=27 women (14 with viable data for pairwise comparison)
Key_Findings: This observational study found no significant difference in objective running biomechanical measures, such as impact G's, braking G's, and pronation excursion, between days when female endurance runners reported menstrual cycle-related symptoms and days they did not. However, the runners reported fewer days running when symptomatic, suggesting that perceived symptom burden may influence training adherence more than objective biomechanical changes. The findings suggest that for this population, biomechanics are stable across symptomatic and asymptomatic days, but the subjective experience of symptoms remains a factor in training.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle and running gait in female distance runners
Citation: Golden D, Moore EM, Weltman A, Statuta S, Hertel J. (2025). GAIT BIOMECHANICS AMONG FEMALE ENDURANCE RUNNERS: COMPARING DAYS WITH OR WITHOUT MENSTRUAL CYCLE-RELATED SYMPTOMS. J Athl Train, 60(11), 783-790.
Key_Findings: This prospective study found no significant difference in objective running biomechanical measures, such as impact Gs and pronation velocity, between days when female endurance runners reported menstrual cycle-related symptoms and days they did not. Although runners reported running less when symptomatic, the objective gait mechanics remained unchanged. The authors suggest that perceived symptom burden may warrant further exploration over objective biomechanical changes.

Research_Topic: Core stability training and menstrual cycle in female athletes
Citation: Zainab, S., Nithyashree, P., Jumanah, R., Kamalakannan, M., Prathap, S., & Kumaresan, A. (2021). A study to compare the effectiveness of core strengthening exercises for phase I and phase II of menstrual cycle in primary dysmenorrhea subjects. Biomedicine, 41(2), 315-317.
Key_Findings: Core strengthening exercises are significantly more effective at reducing pain and improving quality of life when performed during the follicular phase (Phase I) of the menstrual cycle compared to the luteal phase (Phase II) in women with primary dysmenorrhea. The study suggests that timing core stability training to the follicular phase can maximize its therapeutic benefits. This finding supports the concept of menstrual cycle-based periodization for exercise interventions.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle and flexibility in female endurance athletes
Citation: Elorduy-Terrado, A., Torres-Luque, G., Radesca, K., Muñoz-Andradas, G., Saenz-Bravo, M., & Domínguez-Balmaseda, D. (2025). Evaluation the Impact of Hormonal Fluctuations During the Menstrual Cycle on the Performance of Female Athletes—Systematic Review. Muscles, 4(2), 15.
Sample_Size: Multiple studies (Systematic Review of 13 articles with a total sample of 152 athletes)
Key_Findings: This systematic review found that hormonal fluctuations can impact female athletes' performance, with specific evidence suggesting that flexibility is enhanced during the ovulatory phase. However, the review highlights that overall results are inconsistent across studies due to variations in cycle phases studied, lack of standardized methodologies, small sample sizes, and short observation periods. Further research is warranted to provide more conclusive evidence for menstrual cycle-synced training recommendations.

Research_Topic: Tapering strategies and menstrual cycle for female marathoners
Citation: Kubica, C., Ketelhut, S., & Nigg, C. R. (2024). Polarized running training adapted to versus contrary to the menstrual cycle phases has similar effects on endurance performance and cardiovascular parameters. European Journal of Applied Physiology, 124(11), 3433-3444.
Key_Findings: This randomized controlled trial found that an 8-week polarized running training intervention improved endurance performance in both groups of moderately trained female runners. Crucially, there was no additional benefit observed from adapting the training to align with the menstrual cycle phases compared to a contrary, non-aligned schedule. The study suggests that for moderately trained runners, the overall training load and intensity distribution are more impactful than cycle-syncing, though the authors recommend further research with longer interventions and larger sample sizes.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle and altitude training in female runners
Citation: Tagliapietra, G., Citherlet, T., Raberin, A., Bourdillon, N., Krumm, B., Narang, B. J., Giardini, G., Pialoux, V., Debevec, T., & Millet, G. P. (2024). Effect of menstrual cycle phase on physiological responses in healthy women at rest and during submaximal exercise at high altitude. Scientific Reports, 14(1), 27793.
Key_Findings: The study found that the menstrual cycle had negligible effects on most physiological responses to acute high-altitude exposure (3375m) during submaximal exercise. While resting ventilation was slightly higher in the early-follicular phase compared to the mid-luteal phase, key performance indicators like oxygen uptake kinetics, cycling efficiency, and heart rate recovery remained consistent across both phases. The authors conclude that healthy, non-athlete women likely do not need to adjust acclimatization strategies based on their cycle phase.

Research_Topic: Heat acclimatization and menstrual cycle in female endurance athletes
Citation: Giersch, G. E. W., Morrissey, M. C., Katch, R. K., Colburn, A. T., Sims, S. T., Stachenfeld, N. S., & Casa, D. J. (2020). Menstrual cycle and thermoregulation during exercise in the heat: A systematic review and meta-analysis. Journal of Science and Medicine in Sport, 23(12), 1134-1140.
Key_Findings: The meta-analysis of nine studies found a small but significant increase in initial (pre-exercise) and post-exercise internal body temperature in the luteal phase compared to the follicular phase. This suggests that the elevated core temperature associated with the luteal phase is maintained throughout exercise in the heat. However, no significant differences were observed in sweat rate or mean skin temperature across the menstrual phases.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle in masters female runners over 40
Citation: Hamilton, H. M., Yarish, N. M., & Heron, K. E. (2025). Frequency and perceived influence of menopausal symptoms on training and performance in female endurance athletes. PLoS One, 20(12), e0335738.
Key_Findings: This cross-sectional study found that the most common menopausal symptoms among female endurance athletes aged 40–60 were sleep problems, physical/mental exhaustion, and joint/muscular discomfort. The symptoms perceived to have the greatest negative influence on training and performance were joint/muscular discomfort and exhaustion. Furthermore, a higher severity of menopausal symptoms was significantly associated with a greater perceived negative effect on training and performance.

Research_Topic: Postpartum return to running and menstrual cycle restoration
Citation: Deering, R. E., Donnelly, G. M., Brockwell, E., Bo, K., Davenport, M. H., De Vivo, M., Dufour, S., Forner, L., Mills, H., Moore, I. S., Olson, A., & Christopher, S. M. (2024). Clinical and exercise professional opinion on designing a postpartum return-to-running training programme: an international Delphi study and consensus statement. British Journal of Sports Medicine, 58(4), 183–190.
Study_Design: International Delphi Study and Consensus Statement
Key_Findings: A consensus of experienced professionals agreed that training progression for postpartum runners must be modified based on biopsychosocial factors, including lactation and energy availability concerns. Low energy availability, which is a primary cause of menstrual dysfunction (amenorrhea), is a critical factor to monitor alongside musculoskeletal symptoms, sleep, and mental health to ensure a safe and effective return to running. This highlights the importance of addressing energy balance to support the restoration of the menstrual cycle in exercising postpartum women.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle and running performance in adolescent female athletes
Citation: Elliott-Sale, K. J., McNulty, K. L., Ansdell, P., Goodall, S., Hicks, K. M., Thomas, K., Swinton, P. A., & Dolan, E. (2020). The Effects of Menstrual Cycle Phase on Exercise Performance in Eumenorrheic Women: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis. Sports Medicine, 50(10), 1785–1812.
Key_Findings: The meta-analysis found a trivial reduction in exercise performance for both endurance- and strength-based outcomes during the early follicular phase of the menstrual cycle compared to all other phases. Due to the trivial effect size and the low quality of evidence in many included studies, the authors recommend a personalized approach rather than general guidelines for training across the menstrual cycle.

Research_Topic: Amenorrhea and training load in female distance runners
Citation: Wood, A. N., & Soundy, A. (2025). Pharmacological vs. Non-Pharmacological Treatment in the Management of Relative Energy Deficiency in Sport (REDs): A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis. Sports, 13(12), 453.
Key_Findings: Non-pharmacological interventions, which include adjustments to training load and nutritional energy restoration, were found to be effective in managing Relative Energy Deficiency in Sport (RED-S), a condition that includes functional hypothalamic amenorrhea. Specifically, seven out of eight studies (88%) that assessed menstrual function recovery reported statistically significant improvements, with 33% of participants in the intervention groups achieving partial or full recovery of menses. These findings highlight that non-pharmacological strategies, particularly increasing energy availability by reducing training load or increasing caloric intake, are the primary and most effective approach for restoring menstrual function in female athletes.

Research_Topic: Polycystic ovary syndrome and endurance training in women
Citation: Colombo, G. E., Bouzo, X. D., Patten, R. K., Mousa, A., Tay, C. T., Pattuwage, L., Teede, H. J., Redman, L. M., Hirschberg, A. L., & Sabag, A. (2023). Comparison of selected exercise training modalities in the management of PCOS: A systematic review and meta-analysis to inform evidence-based guidelines. JSAMS Plus, 2, 100024.

Research_Topic: Endometriosis and athletic performance in female runners
Citation: Xie, M., Qing, X., Huang, H., Zhang, L., Tu, Q., Guo, H., et al. (2025). The effectiveness and safety of physical activity and exercise on women with endometriosis: A systematic review and meta-analysis. PLoS ONE, 20(2), e0317820.
Key_Findings: This systematic review and meta-analysis of six randomized controlled trials found that physical activity and exercise have a beneficial impact on endometriosis-related symptoms. Key improvements were seen in quality of life, pain intensity, mental health, pelvic floor dysfunction, and bone density. The meta-analysis specifically showed a significant positive effect on the pain aspect of quality of life, control and powerlessness, and emotional well-being.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle tracking apps and training outcomes in female athletes
Citation: McNulty, K.L., Elliott-Sale, K.J., Dolan, E., Swinton, P.A., Ansdell, P., Goodall, S., Thomas, K., & Hicks, K.M. (2020). The Effects of Menstrual Cycle Phase on Exercise Performance in Eumenorrheic Women: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis. Sports Medicine, 50(10), 1813–1827.
Key_Findings: This systematic review and meta-analysis found that exercise performance is only trivially reduced during the early follicular phase of the menstrual cycle compared to other phases. Due to the small effect size and large variation across the 78 included studies, the authors conclude that general guidelines for cycle-synced training cannot be formed. Instead, a personalized approach based on an individual's response to exercise across the menstrual cycle is recommended.

Research_Topic: Wearable technology and menstrual cycle monitoring in runners
Citation: Golden, D., Moore, E. M., Weltman, A., Statuta, S., & Hertel, J. (2025). Gait Biomechanics Among Female Endurance Runners: Comparing Days With and Without Menstrual Cycle–Related Symptoms. Journal of Athletic Training, 60(11), 783–790.
Key_Findings: This observational study found no significant difference in objective running biomechanical measures (e.g., impact Gs, pronation) between runs on days with and without self-reported menstrual cycle-related symptoms in female endurance runners. Although all participants experienced symptoms and ran less when symptomatic, the use of wearable technology (RunScribe sensors) did not detect a change in running mechanics. The findings suggest that perceived symptom burden may not translate to objective biomechanical changes.

Research_Topic: Coach education on menstrual cycle and female athlete training
Citation: Srinivasa Gopalan, S., Liu, S., Mann, C., & Buckler, E. J. (2024). Examining the coach–athlete relationship for facilitators and barriers to healthy sport participation for cyclically menstruating athletes: A systematic review. International Journal of Sports Science & Coaching, 19(4), 1785–1800.
Key_Findings: The systematic review identified a lack of knowledge and awareness, along with poor communication among stakeholders, as primary barriers to healthy sport participation for menstruating athletes. Key facilitators included the presence of female coaches, positive communication, and trust. The study concludes that greater education, increased female representation in sporting roles, and improved collaboration are essential for promoting a supportive culture.

Research_Topic: Menstrual cycle communication between female athletes and coaches
Citation: Srinivasa Gopalan, S., Liu, S., Mann, C., & Buckler, E. J. (2024). Examining the coach–athlete relationship for facilitators and barriers to healthy sport participation for cyclically menstruating athletes: A systematic review. International Journal of Sports Science & Coaching, 19(4), 1133–1152.
Key_Findings: The review identified that the primary barriers to communication are the menstruation taboo, a lack of knowledge and awareness among coaches, and a confusion regarding the responsibility for initiating the conversation. Facilitators include the presence of female coaches, positive communication experiences, and a foundation of trust and closeness in the coach-athlete relationship. The study concludes that greater education, increased female representation in coaching roles, and improved collaboration are necessary to promote healthy sport participation.
